25.heading: Casseau, Vera.
25.title: A Gallery of Pen Sketches in Black and White of our Michigan Friends "as we see 'em"
25.author: by Newspaper Cartoonists' Association of Michigan.
notes: Detroit, W. Graham Printing Co., 1905.
"Compiled and collated by C. 0. Youngstrand."
Cover title: Our Michigan friends "as we see 'em."

Most of the caricatures are signed, and in the front of the book are photographic portraits of cartoonists A.G. Allan (Free Press), Fred C. Nash (Free Press), Fred I. Leipziger (Detroit News), Joseph Kraemer (Detroit News), W.W. Clarke (Detroit News), W.J. Baker (Detroit News), W.T. Bailes (Detroit News), B.R. Thomas (Detroit News), John J. Walsh (Free Press), Vera Casseau (Free Press), Burton R. Law, H.G. Berkey, Louis W. Tower, John F. Gilbert, Fred C. Hunt, Drury V. Haight, and C.O. Youngstrand.

43.heading: Cassette Book Co.
43.title: The Three Musketeers [sound recording]
43.author: [No author]
notes: 1 sound cassette (33 min.) : analog + 1 booklet (48 p. : ill.)
(Classics Illustrated)
An adaptation of the book by Alexandre Dumas.

Summary: "Set in seventeenth-century England and France, this classic rip-roaring tale tells of valour, intrigue, and love. The three musketeers, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, and their companion, D'Artagnan, fight and love their way through a series of hair-raising adventures."

81.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-

82.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
82.title: "First of the Month"

84.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
84.title: "Heart of Pizza"
84.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: A pizza cook throws his dough in the form of a heart; Dilly throws him a kiss and he drops the dough on his head.

85.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
85.title: "How Do You Treat a Whole Regiment for Dislocated Eyeballs?"
85.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Harold takes Dilly to see the soldiers on parade, and they see her as well.

86.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
86.title: "I Sure Talked Myself Out Of That One!"
86.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Whit explains good night kisses as a way to compare girls; Dilly bids him good night.

87.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
87.title: "Is Not The Way to Ask Nice Lady for a Date!"
87.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Two stevedores try out their lines on Dilly Divine.

88.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
88.title: "Marlon Brando!!"
88.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Dilly gets a wrong number call from Marlon Brando.

89.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
89.title: "My Wife Heard Me!"
89.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Tommy the elevator boy dreamed he was on a desert island with Dilly, and he said he hoped they would never be rescued, and now he has a black eye.

90.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
90.title: "Not Another Car Makes a Girl Look So Spectacular"
90.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Rhyming narration about sports cars, their problems of ingress and egress, riding with large dogs, and having no roof in the rain.

91.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
91.title: "On Her, it Looks Better!"
91.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Dilly poses for fashion shots at the zoo, wearing leopard, fox and seal furs in front of the respective animals.

92.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
92.title: "Staying Home with a Good Book"
92.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: After a day of modeling, Dilly turns down three dates on the telephone.

93.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
93.title: "Subway Seat"
93.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: All the men offer their seats, but Dilly chooses to sit with a little boy.

94.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
94.title: "Supermarket Wolf"
94.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Dilly goes to the baby food aisle to get rid of the guy who's following her.

95.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
95.title: "A Sweet, Shy Boy from My Home Town!"
95.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Dilly meets Whit Brown on his return from Paris, with a dancer from the Folies Bergere in his luggage.

96.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
96.title: "There Isn't a Rose That's Born Without a Thorn"
96.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Dilly describes her life as a model in a letter to her mom.

97.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
97.title: "Two Frankfurters with Lots of Mustard"
97.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Whit offers steak, seafood, and Chinese food, and Dilly tells him she likes a man to make the decisions.

98.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
98.title: "Who's the Wise Guy Spraying Perfume Around?"
98.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Harold takes Dilly to see the army post, and she creates a disturbance walking by the barracks.

99.heading: Casson, Mel, 1920-
99.title: "You've Got Nothing On!"
99.author: Alfred James, Mel Casson.
notes: Summary: Dilly is showing her photo album to Harold, and he spots her baby picture.
